citation.article-title: Sediminibacterium salmoneum gen. nov., sp. nov., a member of the phylum Bacteroidetes isolated from sediment of a eutrophic reservoir.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Sediminibacterium salmoneum sp. nov.
Sediminibacterium salmoneum (sal.mo.ne′um. L. n. salmo -onis salmon; L. adj. suff. -eus -a -um suffix used with various meanings; N.L. neut. adj. salmoneum salmon-coloured).
The characteristics are the same as those given in the genus description.
Cells are single rods, 0.2–0.3 μm in diameter and 1.0–1.2 μm long, with gliding motility.
Colonies on R2A agar are salmon-pink, circular, about 0.5–1 mm in diameter and non-spreading after 3 days of incubation at 28 °C.
Growth occurs at 18–37 °C (optimum, 22–28 °C), at pH 6.0–7.5 (optimum, 7.0) and with up to 1 % NaCl (optimum growth in the absence of NaCl).
No growth occurs on TSA, NA, MA or PYG agar.
Gelatin is degraded but pectin, chitin, Tween 80, CM-cellulose and casein are not.
Growth and acid formation occur with raffinose, salicin, lactose, melezitose, d-mannose, trehalose, melibiose, glucose, sucrose and maltose.
Of the latter, raffinose, trehalose and sucrose are the best carbon sources.

Mannitol, d-galactose, l-rhamnose, d-xylose, d-sorbose, d-sorbitol, d-fructose, inulin, d-arabinose, l-arabinose, d-ribose, inositol, citric acid, citrate, sorbic acid, succinate, glycerol, aspartic acid and l-tyrosine are not utilized.
Alkaline phosphatase and weak lipase activities are present, but urease, tryptophan deaminase and arginine dihydrolase activities are absent.

The major fatty acids (>5 %) are iso-C15 : 1 G (24.1 %), iso-C15 : 0 (17.5 %), anteiso-C15 : 0 (9.5 %), iso-C16 : 0 3-OH (7.7 %), iso-C17 : 0 3-OH (7.7 %), anteiso-C15 : 1 A (7.4 %) and iso-C15 : 0 3-OH (7.4 %).
The G+C content of the genomic DNA of the type strain is 40.6 mol%.
The type strain is NJ-44T (=CGMCC 1.6845T =NBRC 103935T), isolated from the sediment of Guanting Reservoir in Beijing, China.
